intro: Amphipterum fuscum, commonly known as the black sandwort, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the coastal regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit and small, dark green leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white, waxy coating. The plant produces clusters of tiny, pinkish-white flowers during the summer months, which are arranged in dense, compact inflorescences. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to withstand harsh coastal conditions, including salt spray and strong winds. Its unique morphology and ecological niche make it an important component of coastal vegetation in its native habitat.
